channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Bei Ling on the Missing Hong Kong Booksellers
item.description: Bei Ling, an exiled Chinese poet, discusses the five men’s fate and why Hong Kong is a center for provocative books about the Chinese political elite.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING
item.media:description: Bei Ling, left, with the publisher Gui Minhai at the Frankfurt Book Fair in 2009. Mr. Bei has known Mr. Gui for more than 30 years.

item.title: Explosion, Said to Be Suicide Bombing, Kills 8 in Northwest Pakistan
item.description: A senior official of the Khyber tribal region said the attacker had detonated an explosive vest at a militia checkpoint just outside the northern city of Peshawar.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN
item.media:description: Security officials at the site of an explosion that was said to be a suicide bombing on the outskirts of Peshawar, Pakistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Week of Attacks, Scores of Civilian Deaths and a Question: Why Them?
item.description: The seemingly random killings last week in Burkina Faso, Indonesia, Iraq and Turkey highlighted the strategy of militants determined to sow fear in disparate corners of the world.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Students and U.S. Universities Connect Through a Third Party
item.description: A private company that conducts interviews of prospective students helps American colleges keep up with the growing number of applicants from China.
item.category: National Assn for College Admission Counseling
item.dc:creator: CAO LI
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese students and parents visiting college recruitment booths at the Education Expo in Beijing in 2011.

item.title: Sinosphere: His Factory Job Gone, a Chinese Migrant Worker Returns Home
item.description: After the sudden closure of a shoe factory, a migrant worker heads back to his home in the countryside. China has been hit hard by the slowing economy.
item.dc:creator: JONAH M. KESSEL

item.title: China G.D.P. Growth at Slowest Pace Since 2009, Data Shows
item.description: The economy grew at a 6.8 percent pace in the fourth quarter, official data released Tuesday showed — the slowest expansion since March 2009.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: An investor at a securities company in Beijing. Investors have been on edge in recent weeks amid renewed turmoil in China’s stock markets and currency exchange rate.

item.title: World Briefing: U.N. Official Cleared in Leak Inquiry
item.description: Anders Kompass leaked information to the French government in 2014 about accusations that French soldiers in the Central African Republic had sexually abused children.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Morocco: Belgian Linked to Leader of the Paris Attacks Is Arrested
item.description: The man, whom Belgian and Moroccan news sources identified as Gelel Attar, is of Belgian and Moroccan background, as were most of those who participated in the attacks.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: World Briefing: Macedonia: Elections Scheduled, but Opposition Threatens Boycott
item.description: Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski submitted his resignation on Friday as part of an agreement forged by Johannes Hahn.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI

item.title: News Analysis: U.S.-Iranian Swaps Pit Compassion Against Costs
item.description: While critics argue that trading prisoners encourages others to target Americans, President Obama has deemed certain releases a reasonable trade-off.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: Andrew Craft/The Fayetteville Observer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, an American prisoner of war now charged with desertion, was secured in exchange for five Taliban detainees.

item.title: Dispute Over Opposition’s Seat at Table Threatens to Push Back Syria Peace Talks
item.description: The new disagreement revolves around the lingering question of who gets to represent the opposition delegation.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: British Have a Go at Trump but Shy Away From a Ban
item.description: Even as lawmakers condemned Mr. Trump during a three-hour debate in Parliament, they appeared to back away from the idea of barring him from entering the country.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Members of Parliament debating on Monday whether to bar the presidential candidate Donald J. Trump from entering Britain.

item.title: Freed by Iran, Matthew Trevithick Quietly Readjusts Back Home
item.description: The researcher, Matthew Trevithick, is decompressing in Massachusetts after being held for 40 days, his family said, and is not ready to speak publicly about his ordeal.
item.dc:creator: JESS BIDGOOD

item.title: Uzbeks Say Inmate Due for Release Died in 2010
item.description: The Uzbek government, lobbied by rights groups and pressured quietly by the United States to free a high-profile political prisoner, has finally revealed a secret: he died five years ago.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: In Surprise Move, Bitter Political Rivals in Lebanon Announce Deal
item.description: Samir Geagea, leader of the Lebanese Forces party, threw his support behind the presidential candidacy of Michel Aoun, whose Free Patriotic Movement is Hezbollah’s main Christian ally in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: English Classes Urged to Combat Muslim Extremism
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron said that classes would be financed for female Muslim immigrants, and warned that some could be deported if they failed to reach certain standards.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Talk to Tehran, but Talk Tough
item.description: The nuclear deal is a triumph for diplomacy. But we must still deter Iranian aggression.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BURNS

item.title: Qaeda Rampage in Burkina Faso Shakes Service Employees
item.description: Hotel and restaurant workers in the African nation’s capital were left feeling vulnerable after an attack claimed 29 lives on Friday.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: The Cappuccino Cafe in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, on Monday. An attack on Friday left 29 people dead and dozens wounded.

item.title: As Freed Americans Rejoin Relatives, Mystery Surrounds One Who Stayed Put
item.description: The reunions came as Iran remained silent about the prisoner deal, and as a mystery deepened about a freed American who chose to stay in Iran.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In Argentina, Rancher’s Discovery Leads to Largest Titanosaur
item.description: A cast of the creature is now at the American Museum of Natural History. Experts hope the fossil discovery will yield new insights.
item.dc:creator: JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:credit: Brian Harkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The head of the Titanosaur sticks out into the hallway at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. The discovery that led to the exhibit started with a find by a rancher in the Patagonia region of Argentina.
